question.body: The acronym 'ACID' in database management system stands for
question.answer: The ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability.

question.body: The term 'Atomicity' in database management system states that

options.a: Each transaction is "all or nothing" i.e. if one part of the transaction fails, the entire transaction fails, and the database state is left unchanged.
options.b: Each transaction is "all or something" i.e. if one part of the transaction fails, the other parts of the transaction many not fail, and the database state is left changed.
options.c: Primary key and foreign key should be atomic.
options.d: Primary key may be atomic, but foreign key can not be atomic.

question.answer: The term 'Atomicity' in database management system states that each transaction is "all or nothing" i.e. if one part of the transaction fails, the entire transaction fails, and the database state is left unchanged.

question.body: The property 'Isolation' in database management system ensures that

options.a: two or more transactions can not be run concurrently if they are using same database resources.
options.b: the concurrent execution of transactions results in a system state that would be obtained if transactions were executed serially, i.e. one after the other.
options.c: the effects of an incomplete transaction might be visible to another transaction.
options.d: ensures that any transaction will bring the database from one valid state to another.

question.answer: The property 'Isolation' in database management system ensures that the concurrent execution of transactions results in a system state that would be obtained if transactions were executed serially, i.e. one after the other.

question.body: The property 'Durability' in database management system means that

options.a: when a transaction has been committed, it should remain so, even in the event of power failure, system crash or errors.
options.b: when a transaction has been committed, it should remain so only, if there is no power failure, no system crash or no errors.
options.c: when a transaction has been committed, it should remain so only, if there is no power failure, no system crash.
options.d: when a transaction has been committed, it should remain so only, if there is no errors.

question.answer: The property 'Durability' in database management system means that when a transaction has been committed, it should remain so, even in the event of power failure, system crash or errors.

question.body: The 'Entity Integrity Rule' in RDBMS states that

options.a: A table may or may not have a unique and not null primary key.
options.b: A table can have a null primary key.
options.c: Every table must have either a primary key or a foreign key.
options.d: Every table must have a unique and not null primary key.

question.answer: The 'Entity Integrity' in RDBMS rule states that every table must have a unique and not null primary key.

question.body: The 'Referential Integrity Rule' in RDBMS states that

options.a: A foreign key can not contain a null value, it always contains only values from a parent table's primary key
options.b: If a primary key is null, the corresponding foreign should also be null.
options.c: A foreign key can contain either a null value, or only values from a parent table's primary key.
options.d: Every must have either a primary key or a foreign key.

question.answer: The 'Referential Integrity Rule' in RDBMS states that A foreign key can contain either a null value, or only values from a parent table's primary key.

question.body: Which one of the statements is incorrect about a Relation(Database Table) following the 1NF(First Normal Form)?

options.a: Two tuples(rows) in a relation(table) can be identical.
options.b: Each attribute(column)value must be a single value(atomic).
options.c: The order of the attributes(columns) is significant.
options.d: Each attribute(column) must have a unique value.

question.answer: According to 1NF, A database table can not have duplicate rows.

question.body: Which one of the following statements is not true if a database relation(table) is in 2NF?

options.b: All non key attributes(columns) are functional dependent on the key attributes(columns).
options.c: The relations(tables) that have a single attribute for a key are automatically in 2NF.
options.d: The relation(table) contains no transitive dependencies.

question.answer: A relation in 2NF can contain transitive dependencies.

question.body: Which of the following statements are true if a relation(table) is in 3NF?

options.c: The relation(table) is in BCNF(Boyce-Codd Normal Form).

question.answer: A relation in 3NF is also in 1NF, and 2NF, but not in BCNF. Also 3NF relation contains no contains transitive dependencies.

question.body: Find the incorrect statement(s) out of following?

options.a: A relation which is in 4NF is also in 1NF, 2NF, 3NF and BCNF.
options.b: A relation which is in 4NF is also in 1NF, 2NF, 3NF but not in BCNF.
options.c: A relation which is in 4NF is also in 1NF, 2NF, 3NF and BCNF.
options.d: A relation which is in 5NF is also in BCNF.

question.answer: The statement "A relation which is in 4NF is also in 1NF, 2NF, 3NF but not in BCNF" is false.
